image.altText: PMC watch house interior 2

props.synopsis: Independent NT politician Yiŋiya Guyula has requested the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples visit the NT. It comes as 255 convicted offenders are being held inside police watch houses.

title.children: Unprecedented prisoner numbers prompts NT politician's plea to UN

image.altText: A map of Australia shows several shaded patches indicating possible cyclones forming around Queensland and northern WA

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting multiple cyclones could form across northern Australia by the end of the week, as tropical lows linger off the coast of north Queensland, in the Gulf of Carperntaria, and off the Kimberley in Western Australia.

title.children: BOM forecasting shows four potential cyclones could form off Australia

image.altText: Urlampe Station

props.synopsis: As the wet season approaches, two outback stations that usually face failing fridges and whopping power bills have installed solar power to save food and money.

title.children: Remote outback stations go solar to protect food

image.altText: Dutton Alice Springs 1

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has committed "in principle" to supporting the NT government's seven point plan to reduce crime in Alice Springs, if the Coalition win government in this year's federal election.

title.children: Dutton commits 'in principle' to Alice Springs crime plan

image.altText: An older woman in a cardigan stands out the front of her house.

props.synopsis: Geoscience Australia says Darwin and the Latrobe Valley are more likely to experience "strong ground shaking". The latter is among the sites the Coalition has identified as a potential home for a nuclear reactor.

title.children: High-risk earthquake zone among sites for potential nuclear reactor

image.altText: The exterior of a building with corrugated metal sheets and a bright red logo, reading APY Art Centre Collective

props.synopsis: The final investigation into allegations of interference in First Nations artwork has concluded, with the Indigenous corporation regulator saying no further action will be taken.

title.children: Investigation into 'white hands on black art' allegations concludes

image.altText: A close-up shot of a boat with three people dressed in black on board.

props.synopsis: The federal government and Border Force say more resources are being devoted to stop illegal boat arrivals off the Northern Territory coast, after an "unprecedented" increase in the past six months.

title.children: Extra resources promised to stop foreign boats arriving in the NT

image.altText: Dish 1

props.synopsis: Kakadu is known for its breathtaking scenery and unique wildlife, but few may be aware that the national park is also a pantry full of native food.

title.children: Kakadu restaurant dishes up 'totally underrated' Indigenous ingredients

image.altText: The tail of a Virgin Australia plane on the tarmac, with other planes lines up behind it.

props.synopsis: Virgin has confirmed it will "indefinitely suspend" its Darwin to Adelaide service, saying it will add more direct flights between the Top End and other capital cities.

title.children: 'Unbelievable': Virgin suspends flights between Darwin and Adelaide

image.altText: Robert F Kennedy Jr speaks into a microphone and points.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's controversial nominee for health secretary fights for support from senators who will ultimately decide whether to give him the job.

title.children: Key moments from RFK Jr's senate committee grilling

image.altText: Sam Abdulrahim standing in a gym with boxing gloves on.

props.synopsis: Police are still searching for the assailant behind the murder of a Melbourne underworld figure, but may face major barriers to apprehending those ultimately responsible.

title.children: Police are hunting Sam Abdulrahim's killer, but they may be out of reach

image.altText: Sam Konstas, Steve Smith and Travis Head

props.synopsis: The axing of Sam Konstas was questioned by a legend as Travis Head, Usman Khawaja and Travis Head benefited from Sri Lankan blunders. Here are the quick hits from day one of the first Test in Galle.

title.children: Quick hits: Icon fumes over Konstas axing as Smith and Head benefit from separate blunders

image.altText: Albanese smiles, standing the prime minister's courtyard.

props.synopsis: It's the start of the election year Anthony Albanese and Jim Chalmers were banking on and the reason why talk of an early poll, either late last year or at the very start of this year, was always misguided.

title.children: Ball is in the RBA's court on rates — and the PM can't stop sweating yet

image.altText: A shopping trolley full of essentials items like fruit, water, and eggs

props.synopsis: The chances of a Reserve Bank interest rate cut in February have improved significantly as price rises ease. So what's behind the inflation pull-back?

title.children: Sticky inflation stopping RBA from making rates cuts is loosening up

props.synopsis: Officials say that three Israelis and five Thais are among the hostages due to be released by Hamas on Thursday

title.children: Hamas to free eight more hostages as Israel-Gaza ceasefire holds

image.altText: A pride flag before Capitol HIll

props.synopsis: Queer people who live and work in the United States are concerned about the executive order on gender that Donald Trump signed in his first week as US president.

title.children: 'Cruel and inhuman': Queer community reacts to Trump's order on gender

image.altText: large crowds before a deadly stampede in India

props.synopsis: India police and state authorities say at least 30 people have died in a stampede at the world's largest gathering of humanity, the Maha Kumbh Mela in northern India.

title.children: Bodies and belongings lie on ground after deadly stampede in India

image.altText: A map of Australia shows several shaded patches indicating possible cyclones forming around Queensland and northern WA

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting multiple cyclones could form across northern Australia by the end of the week, as tropical lows linger off the coast of north Queensland, in the Gulf of Carperntaria, and off the Kimberley in Western Australia.

title.children: BOM forecasting shows four potential cyclones could form off Australia

image.altText: A man with mud on his face in the forrest.

props.synopsis: Australian foreign fighter Oscar Jenkins, who was believed to have been killed by Russian forces after his capture, may still be alive.

title.children: Russia tells Australian government Oscar Jenkins is alive in captivity

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: Colourful mental health graphic showing people with different thoughts.

props.synopsis: Using diagnostic labels for people with mental health issues is on the rise, but this can sometimes hinder rather help, psychologists warn.

title.children: Psychologists warn against overuse of labels for mental health disorders

image.altText: A police car waits in the driveway of a suburban large property

props.synopsis: NSW Police has confirmed that a Sydney caravan filed with explosives had the potential to cause a mass casualty event. However, they say more is needed before this can be designated a terrorism incident.

title.children: Police aren't declaring Sydney caravan explosives a 'terrorism incident'

image.altText: A Noni-B online store is seen on an i-pad

props.synopsis: Mosaic's receivers have failed to find new owners for Millers and Noni B, the last two brands with any hope of a future following the fashion group's collapse

title.children: Thousands of retail jobs lost as fashion group Mosaic closes 252 more stores

image.altText: A close-up of Donald Trump speaking

props.synopsis: The US president said resident aliens who took part in what he called "pro-jihadist" pro-Palestinian rallies will be deported, in an executive order dismissed as "dishonest" and "unenforceable" by critics

title.children: Donald Trump to cancel student visas of pro-Palestinian protesters

image.altText: A smaller man peeks out from behind a larger man as they both stand in a theatre.

props.synopsis: Penn Jillette has been part of one of the most renowned magic duos for more than half a century. We spoke to one half of Penn & Teller while they’re in the country with a new stage show that celebrates the momentous milestone.

title.children: One half of Penn and Teller on magic, lying and Donald Trump

image.altText: A middle-aged bald man with glasses in a suit speaks outside.

props.synopsis: Host of The Party Room podcast, Patricia Karvelas, on why Peter Dutton will only go so far down the Donald Trump path, highlighting eerie similarities between Mr Dutton's new portfolio and Mr Trump's Department Of Government Efficiency (or DOGE).

title.children: ABC News Daily: What’s stopping Dutton going full Trump?

image.altText: A pair of children's shoes

props.synopsis: The Coroners Court of Victoria releases a damning report on Child Protection's failures prior to the deaths of four children between 2015 and 2017.

title.children: Child Protection 'overly optimistic' before 2yo killed, hidden in roof

image.altText: A woman holds her head in her hands

props.synopsis: When a lawyer told her employer she had been sexually assaulted by a third party while on a work trip, she was supported. But when she put in a workers compensation claim nine months later, her employer decided to dispute it — and won.

title.children: 'I don't know why it has to be this hard': Woman loses compensation fight

image.altText: A koala looks down from the fork of a gum tree

props.synopsis: A sanctuary for up to 1,000 koalas and other wildlife is to be established on Kangaroo Island with the hope it will bring tourism and education opportunities while protecting the valuable population of marsupials.

title.children: New koala sanctuary plan for Kangaroo Island

image.altText: Ellyse Perry putting her green baggy cap on, standing in the field during a Test cricket match

props.synopsis: Australia may have comprehensively won the Women's Ashes series, but there is plenty to play for in the standalone Test match at the MCG.

title.children: Australia striving to make history in Ashes day-night Test match

image.altText: People work at desks in an airy room, sitting in front of computers.

props.synopsis: Workers and employers are missing each other. Most job-seekers are looking now, but new research says job ads peak in August.

title.children: Most jobs are advertised in August, but the annual peak of applications is now

image.altText: Young woman with her hair pulled back into a ponytail, wearing glasses, looks into the camera with serious expression.

props.synopsis: Workers say they feel "sad and hopeless" after being indefinitely stood down due to the virus, which can slash crop yields by up to 70 per cent.

title.children: Destructive tomato virus leads to 120 job losses at Victorian farm

image.altText: People walk past white, black, yellow and brown tiles that are stained by brown water marks.

props.synopsis: The pedestrian underpass at Flinders Street station's western end is still lined with original handmade tiles, with heritage laws preventing the replacement of stained and damaged sections.

title.children: Calls to clean up busy thoroughfare at Melbourne's iconic train station

image.altText: The exterior of a building with corrugated metal sheets and a bright red logo, reading APY Art Centre Collective

props.synopsis: The final investigation into allegations of interference in First Nations artwork has concluded, with the Indigenous corporation regulator saying no further action will be taken.

title.children: Investigation into 'white hands on black art' allegations concludes

image.altText: An older woman with short white hair exercising with a pair of pale blue dumbbells.

props.synopsis: An online program aimed at improving diet, exercise and other modifiable risk factors for dementia has resulted in better cognition in older adults, Australian research has found.

title.children: Major Australian study finds lifestyle changes can delay cognitive decline
